Hi, this is Kate from MinuteEarth.

Say you’re in the forest, and you hear the
chirp of a tree frog and the howl of a wolf.

The good news is that the wolf is probably
a lot farther away from you than the frog
- a howl can travel a long way.

But not because wolves are louder; a gray
wolf and a gray tree frog actually call at
about the same volume.

It’s because the howl sound and the chirp
sound behave very differently from each other

- and that has big implications for why some
animals chirp and others howl in the first
place.

Both sounds - all sounds actually - are waves
of pressure that eventually vibrate parts
of your auditory system.

In a chirp, the waves are short and compact,
so there are many waves per second, whereas

in a howl, the waves are long and spread out
so there are far fewer waves per second.

This characteristic - the wave’s frequency
- determines what a sound...well...sounds

like; high-frequency waves sound high-pitched,
and low-frequency waves sound low-pitched.

But a wave’s frequency can also determine
whether it even reaches your ears in the first
place.

High-frequency waves simply aren’t good
at travelling long distances.

The first reason is that, as a wave waves,
it releases energy as heat, and the more frequently

a wave waves, the more energy it releases
as it travels along, and therefore the sooner
it runs out of energy.

So, a chirp will fade out over a shorter distance
than a howl of equal volume.
But there’s also the matter of obstacles.

Low-frequency waves tend to bend around objects
- a tree, a building, a Bigfoot - whereas

high-frequency waves are much more likely
to reflect off them.

It’s like ocean waves hitting the coast;
long, rolling waves kind of flow around it,
while short, choppy waves get interrupted.

In the same way, the short, choppy wave of
a high-frequency chirp is likely to bounce
away before reaching your ears.

That’s why animals that communicate from
afar - say, social animals that roam long

distances, like wolves and elephants, or solitary
animals in search of far-flung mates, like

koalas and humpback whales - use really low-frequency
calls that don’t run out of energy quickly
or bounce off of things along the way.

Elephants’ rumbles - which are so low-frequency
that humans can’t hear them - can reach
herdmates 10 kilometers away.

And, since sounds tend to travel even farther
in water than in air, some whales’ low-frequency
songs can travel more than a thousand kilometers.

Of course, animals can and do use medium-
and even high-frequency calls to communicate,

but since these calls fade out more quickly,
the critters have to be much closer together.

But what high-frequency calls are really good
for is when animals want their calls to bounce
off of stuff.

Bats and dolphins, for instance, use high-frequency
vocalizations precisely because these calls

reflect off the tiniest of obstacles like
an insect, a fish, or - in a bizarre experiment

designed to test the limits of dolphin echolocation
- a kernel of corn.

Which...isn’t exactly something a dolphin
would need.

But in the end, communication - whether it’s
high- or low-frequency - is all about making

sure that your call is able to reach the right
ear.
